s.text: And elections, while a fine way to pick a president, are a decidedly poor way to measure public sentiment.

Quota sampling assumes that the answers of a particular demographic group such as white, 18-to-25-year-old Internet users can be projected to describe the opinions of white 18-to-25-year-olds at large.

Pollsters speak of both the "primacy effect" and the "recency effect," meaning that the first and last choices are more likely to be chosen, particularly when there is a long list of possible answers.
Despite these possibilities, scientific polling has a long, reliable history, whereas "straw polling" has a long history of total unreliability.

Despite these possibilities, scientific polling has a long, reliable history, whereas "straw polling" has a long history of total unreliability.
The print-media straw polls (very different from today's political straw polls but equally inaccurate) featured clip-out coupons that readers sent in to cast ballots for their preferred candidate.
